Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2012 11:03PM vivian1 wrote: Hi neugirl.  I haven't been on the boards for a while so I haven't read your whole story but I read your latest post and had to comment.  I was diagnosed in Feb/12, had a lumpectomy, then mastectomy, then 4 rounds of chemo.  I went through some very bad/sad days but now 9 months later, I can finally say that it is not the first thing I think of in the morning and the last thing I think of at night.  I still have my fears and still have some tears but they are not as often.  I am presently going to a Survivorship group organized by the Cancer Clinic where I was treated.  It is a small group of 5 women who have all had cancer and it is so helpful to be able to vent and share with women who have been through a lot of the same things and understand.  I encourage you to continue here or to talk to someone else who has been through the breast cancer fight before you because no one understands like someone who has been through it.  I'll be thinking of you - take care - stay strong.

Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2012 10:36AM vivian1 wrote: Hi lles, Sorry to hear what you are going through.  I was diagnosed in February and had a lumpectomy done but once the results were in, the surgeon didn't feel that he got it all.  At that point, he told me we could do another lumpectomy or a mastectomy.  I chose then to have a mastectomy to be sure they got it all.  To be truthful, I'm not sure if I would do it again.  It has been very hard to deal with (clothes, bras, prosthetic,etc).I also was shocked to learn a couple of weeks ago, that I could still get a recurrence of cancer on that side even though my breast was gone.  I thought that that was the reason to remove the whole thing.  I do feel more assured, however, than I think I would have been with only a lumpectomy.  For me, time is a great healer, both emotionally and physically.  When I was going through it, it was the first thing I thought of in the morning and the last thing I thought of at night, when I finally got to sleep, but it isn't that way anymore.  The scar and physical limitation on that side are a constant reminder but I have moved on and every day gets better.  I go to a Survivorship meeting and the women there have been a tremendous support. I wish you well - take all the time you need and continue to get support here and from others!
